docs.title: Introduction to nextflow
docs.text: Nextflow is a workflow management system designed to build and run computational pipelines. It is widely used in bioinformatics, data science, and HPC (High-Performance Computing).

docs.title: Why use nextflow?
docs.text:
Nextflow makes workflows:

  • Reproducible – Ensures pipelines run the same way on different systems.
  • Scalable – Works on laptops, HPC clusters, and cloud environments.
  • Modular – Pipelines are broken into reusable processes (modules).
  • Parallelized – Automatically runs tasks in parallel when possible.

docs.title: Nextflow script basics
docs.text: A Nextflow pipeline is written in nextflow DSL2 (Domain-Specific Language 2). Let's look at a simple example:

docs.title: Example: Hello World in Nextflow
docs.text:
#!/usr/bin/env nextflow     

nextflow.enable.dsl=2

process sayHello {
    output:
    stdout

    script:
    """
    echo "Hello, Nextflow!"
    """
}

workflow {
    sayHello()
}

docs.title: Breaking it down:
docs.text:
• #!/usr/bin/env nextflow This tells the system to use Nextflow to execute the script.
  • nextflow.enable.dsl=2 Enables Nextflow DSL2, which is the latest and most flexible version.
  • Defining a process (process sayHello { ... }) A process is a unit of execution. In this case, it runs a small shell command.
  • The script section contains the actual command:
echo "Hello, Nextflow!"
  • Output section (output: stdout) Captures the output of the process, in this case, the text "Hello, Nextflow!".
  • Defining a workflow (workflow { sayHello() }) The workflow section calls the sayHello process. In larger pipelines, this is where you define how different processes connect.

docs.title: Running your first nextflow script
docs.text:
Save this script as hello.nf and run it with:

nextflow run hello.nf

docs.title: Expected Output
docs.text:
If everything is set up correctly, you should see something like this:

N E X T F L O W  ~  version X.X.X
Launching `hello.nf` [random_id] - revision X.X.X
Hello, Nextflow!

This confirms that Nextflow is installed and working correctly!

docs.title: Setting Up Nextflow and Freyja
docs.text: Before we start building workflows, let’s set up our environment by installing Nextflow and Freyja.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Make sure you have: - A Linux or macOS system (Windows users can use WSL). - Java 8 or higher installed. - Python 3 installed.

docs.title: Installing Nextflow
docs.text:
Nextflow requires Java 8+ and can be installed using the following command:

curl -s https://get.nextflow.io | bash
chmod +x nextflow
sudo mv nextflow /usr/local/bin

To verify installation, run:

nextflow -version

docs.title: Installing Freyja
docs.text:
Freyja requires Python 3 and can be installed via pip:

pip install freyja

To check if Freyja is installed correctly run:

freyja --help

docs.title: Alternative installation via conda
docs.text:
If you prefer using Conda, first ensure it is installed. If not, follow the official installation guide.

Once Conda is set up, create a new environment named training-tutorial with Python by running:

conda create -n training-tutorial python=3.9

Activate the environment:

conda activate training-tutorial

Now, install Nextflow and Freyja using conda:

conda install bioconda::nextflow
conda install bioconda::freyja
